captions.text:
Welp, after Sekiro it seems the release schedule
is going to be stumbling around in a post-coital

funk with a shuriken lodged in its forehead
for a while, so let&#39;s do one of my indie double

bills with two recent games that have some
kind of connection between them.

In this case, they&#39;re both named after seven
letter words that end in &quot;ARD&quot;.
And absolutely bugger all else.

I can already tell I&#39;m going to be breezing
through this year&#39;s drought periods like a
rowboat on a ball pit.
So let&#39;s start with Unheard.

Unheard is a puzzley detective game thing
that I had a go at because the premise reminded

me of Return of the Obra Dinn, last year&#39;s
really gosh darningly mainbrace splicingly

good puzzley detective game thing that I was
very sad to find can only be beaten for the

first time once and then becomes little more
than a very atmospheric corpse party.

Unheard is another spin on the concept of
solving a mystery from listening to snatches

of dialogue, and by &quot;snatches&quot; I mean &quot;flipping
great wodges of the stuff.&quot;

The premise is, you&#39;re given a floorplan and
can skip around the last five to ten minutes

before a crime or disaster or the ice cream
man comes, moving your invisible avatar from

room to room listening to conversations between
characters.

From these conversations you must divine each
character&#39;s name and ultimately answer one

or two broad overhanging questions - who was
the killer, who stole the painting, who was

the drummer in Roxy Music from 1980 to 1983,
etc.

And on the whole I&#39;d say Unheard suffers from
a lack of the sheer elegance in design that
made Obra Dinn so hatch batteningly good.

Rather than listening to snatches of dialogue
in the brief moments of constructive debate

and airing of feelings that occur as a person
is getting their head split in half by a giant

crab monster, Unheard has us listen to entire
conversations and hopes that the relevant

pieces of information will craftily sneak
by unnoticed once we&#39;ve all been bored to
death.

The core gameplay is just systematically going
from room to room listening to all the conversations

in turn, and once you&#39;ve heard them all the
answers are usually obvious.

Naming the characters is easy, there&#39;s almost
always one moment where another character

loudly greets them by name as they enter a
room like they&#39;re a fucking special guest
star on the Simpsons.

And there was more than one occasion where
the killer turned out to be the guy with the
obvious creepy psycho voice.

I didn&#39;t get much deductive challenge out
of Unheard is my point.

It felt more like constantly moving inexorably
towards success the more I listened to.
And the scenarios all feel so very contrived.

Partly because it seems odd that everyone
in the building should be having incredibly

relevant exposition-heavy dialogs throughout
the entire five minutes up to the incident

when you&#39;d think at least some of them would
just be talking about lunch or going to the
toilet.

Partly because the actors were apparently
all told that this was their big chance to

get out of radio ads and theme park mascot
costumes and finally get into bigtime shit

like anime dubs and softcore porn, so they&#39;re
all doing massively overblown performances
with their best Bugsy Malone accents.

Alright, maybe my melancholy-tinged love of
Obra Dinn is making me overly cruel about
this.

It&#39;s harmless enough fun and there are at
least a couple of solid &quot;Aha&quot; moments so it

might be worth a look if you&#39;re still jonesing
for another hit of that Obra Dinn &quot;you solved
three more characters&quot; music.

But with its short length and lack of complexity
Unheard has even less replay value than Obra

Dinn, and it doesn&#39;t have that wonderful atmosphere
to drink in, unless you&#39;re keen on the atmosphere

of an amateur dramatics class in a Los Angeles
rehab centre.

So our second game is Outward, an indie open
world RPG with survival crafting elements.

Now, if you&#39;re anything like me, that description
probably has you nodding and smiling and slowly

backing away as your gaze nervously flicks
around checking the exits, but give it a chance,

because the emphasis is more on the RPG and
the survival than the crafting, and at no

point are you given the ability to build a
house.

I&#39;m here to explore and slit up velociraptors,
open world survival RPG developers, why the

fuck would I want to build a house that (A)
cannot move and (B) doesn&#39;t go rawr.

Truth be told I probably wouldn&#39;t have given
Outward much of my time if it weren&#39;t for

two things I found intriguing - first of all,
you start the game, wake up in your nice bed,

yawn, stretch, put on your jeans, head out
the door and then a crowd of people on your
doorstep call you a cunt.

Well, that would&#39;ve livened up the start of
Chrono Trigger or basically any Pokemon game.

Not only do they think you&#39;re a cunt but you&#39;ve
got five days to pay 150 silver and if you

can&#39;t pony up they&#39;re going to burn down your
house or something.

And that&#39;s how you get to grips with the game
- by immediately having to go out and find

a way to pay off the local neighbourhood watch
cum protection racket.

And only after you do that can anything approaching
a plot start.

I like this &#39;cos while some games will just
immediately overload you with plot, characters

and places to go, Outward doesn&#39;t give you
much beyond one simple goal and leaves you
to figure out the rest.

Maybe you&#39;ll do some sidequests, maybe you&#39;ll
hunt and scavenge enough stuff to sell or

maybe you&#39;ll just hop aboard the nearest boxcar
and resign yourself to a life of furiously

sucking dick like a starving hedgehog in a
worm farm.

The other feature that impressed me early
on was the combat, and specifically the fact

that you can press a single button to ditch
your backpack where you stand and can come

back for it when you&#39;re finished dodge rolling
the enemy&#39;s balls off.

Many things would benefit from a dedicated
&quot;immediately strip down to your pants&quot; button.
Dark Souls, awkward job interviews etc.

Sadly, Outward couldn&#39;t sustain its appeal
after the good first impression.

Mosey on back to the start of this paragraph
and note my usage of the phrase &quot;anything
approaching a plot.&quot;

&#39;Cos most of the time Outward doesn&#39;t so much
approach a plot as hang around outside its
house until somebody calls the police.
The main point of the game is travelling.

There&#39;s no fast travel, everything&#39;s spread
out like your mum&#39;s legs at a farmer&#39;s market

and travelling by night is about as advisable
as bobbing for hair dryers so every journey

is a little mini-adventure in mapreading,
resource management and picking your battles,

but the characters you&#39;re travelling to are
rather hollow and little more than nodes connecting
the journeys.

I finally reach the next city and the person
I&#39;m supposed to meet and they&#39;re like &quot;Good
boy!

Now why don&#39;t you go back to the starting
city and see if they need anything.&quot;

I thought this game was called Outward, not
Outward Inward Shake It All Aboutward.

I&#39;m also not a fan of the way you never truly
die.

It&#39;s a fairly universal measure of a game&#39;s
frustation: how long it takes, after failure,

to get back in a position to have another
crack.
And this game&#39;s like &quot;Oh no you died.

Never mind, just have a six hour rest to get
your health back, scavenge up more food and

water, figure out where the fuck we just spawned
you and then trek back over.&quot;
&quot;Or I could... reload a save?&quot;

&quot;No you fucking couldn&#39;t, we literally won&#39;t
let you.&quot;

And I don&#39;t feel enough sense of purpose to
mitigate the annoyance.

So in conclusion, Outward doesn&#39;t go anywhere,
and Unheard won&#39;t shut up.

Next week, a game called Piers Morgan about
a human being who deserves to be alive.
